name: Micro mouse
description:
This project is very complicated. Step 1. either one or two teams each build a â€œmouseâ€ - a small robot that has wheels to move it as fast as possible, and sensors so it knows where it is. Step 2. After discussing what a search algorithm is, we can try to implement one on the Arduino. This shows the mouse how it can move through a maze. The problem is, we need a maze. Step 3. Construct a maze from wood which is just large enough for the mice to turn and move.


This project will probably have to happen later in the summer if at all. I listed 2 days as the duration, but this is counting one day of building and one day of programming/explaining how that stuff works, and Iâ€™m not sure how or when we would build the maze.
materials: Wellâ€¦ thereâ€™s a lot. Shaiel already sent a picture of a bunch of Arduino parts which are very useful, although we may need infrared sensors which are used to keep the robot in a straight line, and tiny wheels and motors for it to use.
goals: Student should understand what a search algorithm is, and the basics of building small robots. The project supports teamwork and shows the value of the engineering cycle.

name: Catan ×’×“×•×œ (for real)
description:
(Shaiel and Yehoshua made this together)
Create a Catan gameset in the Pink Room, paint it, et cetera. . . 

This will be used to teach strategies on how to dominate in Catan


Could be that this is longer than two days; possibly make in to several projects.
materials: Pink room and wood supplies required for building large model of the game
goals:
Kids will learn how to cut hexagons on a tablesaw
Kids will have a working version of Catan
Kids will make minor design adaptations together
Kids will learn how the game itself is used, so they can make the above decisions
and also. .  . so we can create our own ×”×¨×›×‘×”(expantion) (with . . . dragons?  tanks? Daleks? ships? TUNNELS?  Goblins?  etc.)
categories: Geeky, Innovative, Subversive, Gaming, Art, Advanced, Hits many notes, including simply building, but also analysing the game to know what best works for an expansion.

name: Big/Small Solution
description:
There are problems in this world. The kids need to design and draw their tool/machine to solve a problem they are given/choose and present it to the group. 
The catch is, it has to fit into something (example: q backpack).


If there are many kids split them into groups and then they can also learn team work. 
Pivot with the kids! Don't get stuck on what you want.
materials: Paper and pencils
goals: The kids expand their imagination. And expand their understanding of "the bigger picture" and problem solving.

name: Human homunculi
description: Have the kids split up into groups and test different things on different parts of their bodies for which is the most sensitive, then rank them and have them draw each body part on a separate piece of paper according to how sensitive it is, and then put all the papers together on the floor to make one big homunculus
materials: Paper, drawing supplies, tape, various misc (qtips, toothpicks, etc)

name: (WATER) floating fountain
description:
Build floating fountain/s


Could be expensive
materials: Clear acrylic tubing, faucet heads, pumps, small clear hose, some kind of bowl or pot

name: (WATER) greedy cup siphon
description:
Build a greedy cup siphon (tutorial in notes) and customize it 


https://youtu.be/Cg8KQfaT9xY
materials:
Acrylic sheets, hot glue, dye for water, some way to cut acrylic sheets, funnel, bucket. 
Alternatively, two sets of straws/tubes of slightly different sizes and some plastic cups

name: (WATER) Tesla valves
description:
Create and test Tesla valves with water/marbles


https://youtu.be/suIAo0EYwOE
materials:
Not entirely sure
Could use tubing, wood grooves, maybe Lego, or something else. 
I'm open to suggestions

name: Creatures of the speculative deep
description:
Discuss and draw potential ocean life under real or invented circumstances 


Can be continued or expanded into more speculative activities
materials: Drawing supplies

name: Geeks in Kitchen
description:
Taste tests/smell tests
Temp experiments
Socratic questioning about scientific method
USE of scientific method/categories/etc


Samurai Staff Rock
materials:
Pencils/paper (Graph paper helps)
2 computers

Flour, Sugar, Rosemary, Salt, Oil/butter, Potatoes (optional)
Onions?, Garlic

Frying pan/gas, Electric oven, Table covers will make cleanup easier
Scales
Cooking supplies/measuring cups/spoons/

Shaiel's credit card

Timer

Know about food allergies
goals:
- Designing a metric for evaluating the rosemary mashed-potatoes is a group decision.
- Making mashed potatoes - simple, measurable, tasty, shared experience. . .
- Mistake-recovery can be emphasised if there's an organic mistake - possibly we can innovate something in the method (add an egg? add a flavour?)
- establishment of a control group is an 'everyone-activity'
- Evaluation of changes to variables is an extensive process

name: Taste experiments
description:
Do experiments and prove physics concepts of mechanics using a launcher. We will build a cannon which launches small projectiles. We can explain a bit of how newton's physics work and how to predict where a projectile will land. We will repeat the launch at different angles/heights and record how far the projectile goes. Using some math we can find the mass and prove how to calculate the projectile's distance from an angle.


Note that we have no notes
materials:
Either lego or pink room's materials like wood
Meter stick
Computer to calculate math (maybe)
Paper to write results
goals: The students to understand some basic physics and to each feel like they contributed something to the experiment. If the experiment goes wrong (like an explosion...) the campers need to adapt and change the goals, they can learn resilience. One issue could be with air resistence.

name: Machine Learning
description:
Talk about and discuss how machine learning models work, and what theyâ€™re used for. We would show how a simple one can be made using an online tool, and show the power of the large language models that have gotten much more powerful and popular since we did this activity last year. 


Note that this might need to wait until a certain technology is available to us and could be purchased when it is
materials: Computers, laptops maybe
goals: To understand how neural networks function and why they are so important and how generative ai can be useful and harmful.

name: Hole Lot of Lego
description:
We'll challenge the Campers (split into small groups) to build a robot to drive up a ramp (Lego Room). 
The catch is, at the top of the ramp there will be a cutout the robot has to fit through, increasingly getting smaller as the challenge continues, challenging their ingenuity and resource management.


For number of participants; I'm imagining a few groups of 3 give or take
materials:
Paper/Card-board to cut out 
Piece of wood for ramp
Something to lean the ramp on
goals:
You fulfill the whole Create, Design, Invent, Build values with the designing of the robot and running tests
Resilience - The name of the game is resource management, you need to drive up the ramp while keeping the essential parts to have a functioning compact robot
Engagement - the robot succeeding is a group victory, the whole activity is in the same boat during the challenge

name: Keeping chronology
description:
Discuss, design, and compare different time keeping devices
Candles, clocks, sundials, hourglass 


Needs discussion
materials:
Not entirely sure, maybe pink room.
Needs discussion

name: (FIRE) Rubens tubens
description: Do Rubens tube again
materials:
Metal pipes/cans
Lighters
Balloons
Speaks

name: Ancient Mesopotamia
description:
Teach the campers how writing evolved, how it started in ancient Mesopotamia, and teach them how to write in Cuneiform.
After we've written our names and labeled the camp rooms, we will learn one of the oldest race-games in the world, The Royal Game of Ur.
(If we have time left over, we could inscribe, as a group, the lyrics of a popular song, or write a story, or Shaiel's Haiku in Cuneiform...)


Depending on the number of boards, and the amount of clay that is feasible to get, those factor limit the number of campers we`ll be able to have.
I'll have to test Cuneiform

Cuneiform videos
History
How-to
Royal Game of Ur:
https://youtu.be/WZskjLq040I - To get the feel of the game

Videos for your fun, might use first two for the activity
materials:
A projector to show the symbols, maybe show an instructional video 

For Cuneiform:
(Some clay), Plastecine, Cut popsicle sticks,Plastic bowls with water, We could be working on newspapers to minimize mess

For the Royal Game of Ur
A lot of dice (that need to be modified to be half covered/half normal; 4 per board [D4 if we want to be true to the original, 2 tips marked])
Paper with the board printed/drawn on it (or we could make an actual board with wood)
Back-gammon pieces (or any distinct, easy-to-play-with pieces; 14 (7 of each color) per board)
goals:
Engagement - Each camper will be pressing their own name into the clay and have a small chunk to take home with them.
Create - it's a whole cool writing system, over 5000 years old, we are re-learning, you are creating a piece of history.

name: Bottle Marimba
description:
Make a 2-3-octave xylophone from bottles.  (We have a lot of bottles.)

This requires some kind of stand. . . a good number of plastic bottles, valve stems, a bike pump, a drill, and mallets to play with.  I think we'll start with a prototype and show that it can be done.
materials:
Valve stems (could be taken from old tyre inner-tubes but they don't cost much)
Bike pump
Tuner
Making of a stand 

Many bottles (I assume some will explode)

Drill with stepper bit to put valve stems into bottle caps
goals:
Create-design-invent-build  

Inclusion (it can't be done alone)

Belonging (other people will use what we make) (we hope, at least. . .)

name:
(Yehoshua Steinitz's) 
Catan Gadol 2.0
description: Plan the mechanics of a Catan expansion, and, cut/paint/build a larger model of Catan for purposes of the expansion.  (Hexagon jig for table saw. . .)
materials:
6 or 8 mm plywood for board, probably about a half-sheet.

Paint
goals:
Students create mechanics of a Catan expansion.  Add, maybe, TANKS or HELICOPTERS, FACTORIES, or I don't know what.

In parallel, students (maybe the same students) build a long-lasting expansion, possibly from a larger, more durable board.

name: Our Hacker Camp 2023
description:
Starting 1st day,
We'll design a canvas that will eventually have the hand stencils of all of this year's camp.
We'll also do other art things to make Camp our own.


General first-day art activity
materials:
Paper (Bristol, colored)
Art supplies - Paint (Gouache), Glue, Scissors
goals:
Community+Belonging - We are striving to have a canvas that has us all included on it, our hands, with which we create Camp.
Create - It's an Art activity, decorating our campus and making it home

name: Rotating Robots
description:
We give the campers a challenge, doesn't need to be anything specifically (Drive up a ramp, etc.), but the interesting part is, is after a while, each one of the groups needs to exchange robots, and continue another teams progress.


I'm unsure how well this activity might play out
It would be awesome if everyone shares, and sees the fun in adding on to the progress of the Robot
But groups could get annoyed at "setbacks", if a group inherits a "less-advanced" robot, and not enjoy another team succeeding, "getting all the credit for their hard work"...
Sharing ideas in a safe way is a core value of camp, forcing it as a challenge might cause damage...
materials:
Some robot brains
A plank of wood for the ramp (or something to satisfy the challenge we end up choosing).
goals:
Design/Build - Typical Lego Robot activity in the pink room
Community - The robots are shared, like intellectual safety for sharing ideas, a robot that succeeds will have all of the teams' finger-prints on them

name: Milling Lumber - Grunt work
description:
Pretty boring, lots of repetitive tasks.  Maybe good for teaching Pink Room.

We plan to mill lumber salvaged from this floor nearby (oak) 
Maybe also take apart/recover some hardware from cabinets I saw getting chucked (they do this every year) at the Boyar boarding school.
materials: Just tools.  And (if milling) some raw materials.

name: Garden bed preparation
description:
Pull out the irrigation pipes (possibly relay new ones from the source)

Arrange cardboard/karton base
Lay soil and compost in raised bed OVER cardboard

Eventually plant peppers and garden plants in the bed created.


I wrote half-day, because, it's mostly worth doing this in the morning.
materials:
Brown cardboard, the more/the larger, the better

Either:
Irrigation pipe
Ground staples

Or:
Scythe (to cut around irrigation pipe and pull it out)
Chairs (to hold the pipe a half-meter up while we wrestle the dry weeds under the cardboard
categories: Geeky, We probably want a few other categories in here.

name: Keyring chainmail
description: Make chainmail out of keyrings
materials: Need a lot of keyrings

name: Dice bags of holding
description:
Make dice bags


Not sure how to make this coop exactly

Sewing supplies
That's it

description:
Design a world and then figure out what kind of life would evolve on a world like that or vice versa
Have the kids split into groups and focus on one aspect 


Could also go for more days
Can be run multiple times because each one will be very different

name: The anatomy of fear
description:
Discuss fear and it's roots and branches
Talk about how it relates to us personally 


Went really well last year

Teach the sacred geometry art style/math

name: Hujenga (TIMBER!!)
description: Make a huge version of the game jenga. First by using the pink room to cut all the wood pieces to be the same, and then painting all the blocks.

name: Optics
description:
Teaching optics (physics of light) using lasers and mirrors. 


It would be cool to be at the end of color week, ideally on a Thursday so we can use telescope
materials: white board and markers

name: Cup Drop Challenge resisting gravitational acceleration by creating contraptions to carry containers of di- hidrogen monoxyde
description:
Classic egg drop with a twist. instead of an egg you have a standard coffee cup with a cover full of water. The goal is to drop the cup from about 2 meters with the least amount of water spilled with the materials are given.


Based of the Israel physics competition in honor of the landing of the perseverance rover in 2021.
materials: 2 bags of marshmallows, large piece of cardboard, foam, 5 plastic bags, string, hot glue, scissors, 1 pack of skewers, 1pack of straws
goals:
A physical understanding of soft landings.
Teamwork, making one project with multiple people.
How to make do with the resources you are given.

name: Inter-room Cable cars
description:
Create a cable car system that travels through the hallway and reaches different rooms (ideally reaches inside them but just outside the doors is possible too). There will be multiple cable cars with small engines (having an electrical wire is too dangerousâ€¦), pulley wheels on the top and bottom halves of milk cartridges. This system will remain up after the project ends and can be used by all to deliver things from room to room in an unnecessarily complicated way and see it whizz above us.


Some access to pink room would be nice but not enough to justify taking up the roomğŸ‘
materials: A lot of thin but strong rope/string, milk cartridges (depending on how many carts we make), pulley wheels, screws and thin metal pieces.
categories: Innovative, Camp addition, cars and trucks and things that go.

name: 3D design
description: Campers use an online software to design something to 3D print and get later. along with learning some concepts of 3D design
materials: Computers

name: Cyanotype/Blueprints/Sun-painting with chemistry
description:
Day 1: (counselors)
Mix potassium ferricyanide (40g) into water (400ml)
Mix ferric ammonium citrate (100g) into water (400ml)
let dissolve for 24 hours

Day 2: Counselors or cool kids:
Mix equal parts of each solution.  It will be good for about 2 hours.
Paint white paper or white cloth (or both) with solution.  Let air dry in dark.
Keep paper/cloth in dark.

Day 3: Anyone
Put something dramatic (leaves, flowers, feather, et cetera) on the paper or cloth.
Cover with a sheet of glass.
Expose to sunlight for 10-20 min, keeping positions as well as possible.

It will turn yellow/amber.
Rinse in a tray of water for 5-8 min.  Rinse again, until water is clear.
Rinse in diluted hydrogen peroxide to lock the cyan in place.

Hang dry on a clothesline.  After it dries, it's not going to change colours on its own, but, oils in our hands, et cetera, might cause changes in colours.





Some parts take very little time, and some parts take more.

There's a  lot of down-time here.
materials:
White cloth and/or strong paper
potassium ferricyanide 
ferric ammonium citrate
hydrogen peroxide

(Distilled water?  Jerusalem water is very mineral-hard, so yes distilled is better.)

name: Mechanical physics with Lego.
description:
Teach Mechanics and Kinetics with the use of Lego as a physical representation and visualizer for the physics taught.  
We will teach the kids part by part these branches of physics and demonstrate with Lego, once we teach them enough we will challenge them to build something with a goal that they want to reach using the physics they leaned (such as trying to launch a ball as far as possible and they will figure out the best angle of launch).
materials: Lego, possibly robots with a computer for programing, white board and markers.

name: loosing your marbles
description: To make a marble run out of Lego against a wall. The objective is to make the longest and most complicated one.
materials: Lego, marbles, a wallâ€¦

name: Joint joining
description:
Teach a bunch of wood joints in the pink room 


Needs research
materials:
Pink room
Wood
Preferably different colors so you can see the joints better

name: (FIRE) smoke signals
description:
Teach kids how to communicate via smoke signals 


Not sure about this one
Needs research
materials:
Wood for smoke
Wood for creating signals

description:
Teach kids different dire starting methods
Bowing, soda can and chocolate wrapper, plastic bag and water, flint and steel, grooving, magnifying glass
materials: Wood, sawdust/kindling, string, sticks, knife/woodcarving tools, buckets, water, plastic bags, soda cans, chocolate wrappers, magnifying glass

name: (FIRE) paraffin autoignition
description:
Make paraffin wax essplode


Not long enough for a full activity, should be combined with other fire or just done during a rundown for fun.
https://youtube.com/shorts/90iUn6lJdbE?feature=share
materials: Glass beakers, long tongs, ice, water, paraffin wax, burner, safety gear

name: (FIRE) smoke disposal
description:
Hard to explain. Watch video in notes


Not long enough for a full activity, should be combined with other fire activities.
https://youtube.com/shorts/fudymWKAO04?feature=share
materials: Glass beaker, paper, lighter/long matches, toothpicks, rubbing alcohol

name: (FIRE) new vs old pennies
description:
Show the difference between new and old pennies with fire


Not long enough for a full activity, should be combined with other fire activities
https://youtube.com/shorts/FZKQUChkttY?feature=share
materials: Old and new pennies, glass beakers, tongs, blowtorch, rubbing alcohol

name: (FIRE) northern light
description:
Create copper chloride 
(takes a full day of sitting to dissolve, so will do it at rundown day before to show how it has dissolved by the next day)
Then add aluminum to create small puffs of hydrogen gas which burn bluish green 


Not long enough for a full activity, should be combined with other fire activities.
https://youtube.com/shorts/afvlM6sRQpE?feature=share
materials: Copper chloride, 3% hydrogen peroxide, Hydrochloric acid, Copper metal, glass beakers, lighter

name: make-your-own-earthquake
description: to build a structure out of tape and straws/ marshmallows and toothpicks, then stick it in a pan filled with jelly, then shake the pan with the structure sitting in jelly to simulate an ear quake and see if the structure can withstand it
materials: straws and marshmallows OR straws and tape
goals: create, design, invent, build, engagement, geek

name: playing God
description:
to make up an animal and discuss the biology behind it (eg. what would be the animal most likely to survive and why/ ideal animal)


im not sure if this would just be a discussion or also something where the kids can draw and design, might be something worth discussing
materials: just the kids ideas and voices

name: Tracking migration
description: To take wind-up toys and track their patters, then put paint on their feet and paint a picture using their different patterns
materials: Wind up toys, paint

name: Wooden Fiber Aircraft Accelerator AKA Paper Airplane Launcher
description:
1. Build paper airplane launcher out of motor + wood + spinning thing or maybe Lego
2. Fold an already existing paper airplane design and test it to see itâ€™s weaknesses/strengths
3. Explain a bit of complicated physics to the campers on how paper airplanes fly and how exactly certain parts of it affect lift and drag
4. Campers split into groups and work on designing or tweaking an existing design
5. Scientifically test the designs on the launcher and record distance to see which changes worked the best
6 (given enough time). Build the best paper airplane possible given everything learned from the day
materials: Lots of paper! Either legos or wood + motor + battery
goals: The goal is to build a super paper airplane and to learn a bit of how real planes fly. We will have to go through the design process to understand how to best construct our paper airplanes

name: Wave Function Collapse
description:
This is a coding activity.
The first half of the day involves an algorithm called "Wave Function Collapse". It's used in game design and a demo can be found here: https://jaxry.github.io/wave-function-collapse/.
We will experiment with the default options and then make our own pixel art to give the algorithm. Then, I'll explain some of the way it's coded and why certain functions make it work. The campers can even try and code a bit of the algorithm themselves, although it is very complicated.
The second half of the day is about the other meaning of "Wave Function Collapse" which comes from quantum mechanics. It explains how quantum particles can be in many different states all at the same time, but "collapse" as soon as we inspect them. With this, I'll explain how to make requests to run code on real quantum computers using Python and Qiskit (https://qiskit.org/).


Note that this activity requires explaining and sitting around for a while, which is to be expected on computer activities
materials: 0.42 computers per camper
goals: To learn about quantum mechanics, a cool algorithm, and to get the campers introduced to something that's out of their comfort zone, even if they are expert coders.
categories: Geeky, Nerdy, Computers, Gaming, Art, Explosive, Advanced

name: HyperDimensional theory
description:
Discuss and analyze existence in other dimensions (0-4/5)


Last time it was finished early
materials: Mostly discussion

name: (EARTH) stone carving
description:
Carve designs into stone


This will probably be a trial and error thing
materials: Hammers/mallets, chisels, lots of big rocks

name: (FIRE) candle snuffing
description:
Design and implement different ways to snuff out candles


Here's an example
https://youtube.com/shorts/AvmwJWheT80?feature=share
materials: Candles, toothpicks, skewers, cups, water, paperclips, misc stuff from stuff room

name: Bestagons Game
description:
Invent the game that Adam and the Think Higher team wanted to make, but thought was too complicated (to prove them wrong, and also bestagons). The essence of the idea is to create a 3D board game thatâ€™s dynamic, meaning the board can look different each game. This would involve using the bestagon device to cut wooden hexagons to use in the game. Each tile serves a different purpose in the game and they can be shuffled around and stacked in different ways to make the game unique each time itâ€™s played. Itâ€™s a long project because it involves cutting wood, painting, and brainstorming how the game is going to work. It canâ€™t be too complicated, but it needs to have some element of skill, not just luck, although some luck is good too.


The game they made in Think Higher is super cool!
materials: Wood for bestagons, paper for brainstorming (auto correct says brainwashing??), pencils, paint & brushes, cardboard and/or cardstock for cards if we need them
goals:
Some questions to think about:
What makes a game well designed? How can we make the game fun, easy to learn, engaging, and simple, yet not too complex, all at the same time? Itâ€™s a challenge of thinking of loads of ideas but realizing that not all of them will actually work for the game. How can playtesting and balancing help make the game more fun? How can we make sure players donâ€™t get board if itâ€™s not their turn? How can we include players with disabilities such as color blindness or dyslexia (separate by icons vs. colors or text)?

name: Hacker Camp Political Parties AKA Mini M.U.D.
description:
This is an activity I already ran this year, but itâ€™s worth recording what we did.
We split into groups of 4-5, although we shouldâ€™ve kept the max at 4 per group. Each group creates 5 things.
1. The team name. This can be something from geek culture, hacker camp culture, or whatever. This year we had â€œThe Lathe Rebellionâ€, â€œNGGYUâ€, and â€œDemopracyâ€
2. The slogan. This is a one sentence explanation of what the team is going to do if they win the election.
3. Hacker camp political opinions. Which doctor in Dr. Who is the best? Do we really need another lathe? The teams need to decide on their opinion on some of them. We gave about 10 examples to start from, and they had lots more.
4. The poster. This needs to be planned and has the name of the team, their slogan, and some artwork from what they are trying to do, like popcorn for the team who want to have us eat popcorn at movie nights.
5. The video. The campers decide on a filming plan for their video which might include an interview or showcase of what the team is planning on doing if everyone votes for them. They can also be edited if thereâ€™s enough time.

Lastly, at synthesis the videos are shown and all of camp votes on whichever team they like the most.


Here are some of the â€œpoliticalâ€ opinions I thought of to get them started:
Should we eat strawberry pizza at camp?
Do we need another lathe?
Should we eat lunch inside or outside?
Is a movie night better or is game night better?
Which is the best room in camp?
Are hexagons really the bestagons?
Campers can also suggest more
materials: Poster paper, large pieces. Markers, pencils, normal sized paper for brainstorming. Camera/ phone camera and editing app for the video portion. Campers canâ€™t use their phones so staff phones work well for video and editing.
goals:
The goal is to show the campers how much a team can help them complete their own goal: winning the election. They had to think of what would get the most votes and how to make it funny at the same time.

I just thought Iâ€™d mention that this activity isnâ€™t supposed to have anything to do with real life politics.
